author: By Alex Marshall
title: ‘The Power of the Dog’ Wins Best Film at Wide-Open BAFTAs
description: Jane Campion won the best director prize at Britain’s Academy Awards for her tense western in an evening that saw a host of surprise winners.
content: LONDON — “The Power of the Dog,” Jane Campion’s tense Western about two clashing brothers on a Montana ranch, starring Benedict Cumberbatch and Jesse Plemons, was the big winner at the EE British Academy Film Awards in London on Sunday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Review: In ‘Misdemeanor Dream,’ Speaking to the Unseen
description: This experimental work, presented by La MaMa and the Indigenous theater ensemble Spiderwoman Theater, is full of enchanting stories but is missing a few threads.
content: The fairies have stories to share. At least the ones in “Misdemeanor Dream,” who tell tales in English and Native languages, but also via movement and dance, of the births of constellations, the celestial romance that begets all sentient life. But the thicket of music, overlapping dialogue, sounds and projections in this experimental work, presented by La MaMa and the Indigenous feminist theater ensemble Spiderwoman Theater, doesn’t always come together to convey these enchanting stories; in fact, this patchwork often makes the show indecipherable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
title: Russia Asked China for Military and Economic Aid for Ukraine War, U.S. Officials Say
description: Jake Sullivan, the U.S. national security adviser, plans to meet with a top Chinese official on Monday in Rome to discuss the war and China’s role.
content: WASHINGTON — Russia asked China to give it military equipment and support for the war in Ukraine after President Vladimir V. Putin began a full-scale invasion last month, according to U.S. officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: The base attacked in western Ukraine has been a hub for foreign militaries.
description: The base outside Lviv that was attacked by Russian forces early on Sunday was a key link between Ukraine’s armed forces and Western militaries before the war.
content: The base outside Lviv that was attacked by Russian forces early on Sunday was a key link between Ukraine’s armed forces and Western militaries before the war — and has become an important logistics hub and training center for foreign fighters since Russia’s invasion began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 14, 2022
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Brent Renaud, an American filmmaker killed in Ukraine, captured the human toll of war.
description: Mr. Renaud’s final assignment was documenting refugees fleeing across bridges in Irpin, Ukraine.
content: When Brent Renaud, an award-winning American filmmaker and journalist, was killed in Ukraine on Sunday, he was there to do what he had done throughout his career: bear witness to the world’s most dangerous stories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg
title: Oil Prices Drop Slightly as Market Volatility Eases
description: A barrel of oil is trading at roughly $110, while gasoline is at $4.30 on average in the United States.
content: Oil prices drifted lower at the start of trading on Sunday evening, a respite from the volatility of recent weeks as Russia’s assault on Ukraine grinds on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: The Skiing Aigners Are a Nation Unto Themselves
description: The visually impaired siblings and their guides accounted for more medals at the Beijing Paralympics than several powerhouse countries.
content: YANQING, China — The 2022 Winter Paralympics ended Sunday with China winning, by far, the most medals, 61, followed by the undaunted Ukrainian team and Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Government Is Flailing, in Part Because Liberals Hobbled It
description: A legal dispute over enrollment at Berkeley shows how the old ways of environmentalism won’t cut it in a new era of climate crisis.
content: There’s a strange story unfolding in Berkeley, Calif., right now. That may present as a tautology, but bear with me. This one provides a window into a problem that endangers us all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Rampaging Camel Kills Two Men at a Tennessee Farm
description: The camel was put down after it charged at law enforcement officers who were trying to move one of the victims, the authorities said.
content: Two men were killed by a camel that had gotten loose at a farm in Tennessee on Thursday, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: The Key to a $4 Billion Fraud Case: A Banker Who Says He ‘Lied a Lot’
description: Only one person is likely to ever face trial in the United States over the looted billions from a Malaysian sovereign wealth fund. The case hangs on his former boss at Goldman Sachs.
content: It seemed a facetious question, one intended to provoke the star witness: “Do you think you are good at lying?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: At Chelsea, Nervous First Steps Into an Uncertain Future
description: Locked shops and rivals’ taunts greeted fans at Chelsea’s first home game since sanctions against Roman Abramovich cast their team’s future in doubt.
content: LONDON — For the Chelsea fans who headed to Stamford Bridge for the team’s first home game since its world crumbled last week, signs of the club’s new, diminished circumstances were clear to see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Brent Renaud, Crusading Filmmaker, Is Killed at 50
description: He traveled around the world and the United States making documentaries about urgent moral issues. He was shot to death while filming in Ukraine.
content: Brent Renaud, who with his brother, Craig, formed a Peabody Award-winning documentary film team that drew attention to human suffering, often working with major news organizations like The New York Times, was fatally shot in Irpin, a suburb of Kyiv, on Sunday. He was 50.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Patrick Kingsley
title: ‘Things Will Only Get Worse.’ Putin’s War Sends Russians Into Exile.
description: Thousands of Russians saw their comfortable, middle-class lives fade overnight with the invasion ordered by President Vladimir V. Putin.
content: ISTANBUL — They lined up at ATM’s, desperate for cash after Visa and Mastercard suspended operations in Russia, swapping intelligence on where they could still get dollars. At Istanbul cafes, they sat quietly studying Telegram chats or Google Maps on their phones. They organized support groups to help other Russian exiles find housing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: How Readers Around the World Are Praying for Ukraine
description: “The worst is yet to come, Lord, if you do not stop it.”
content: Each morning over the past few weeks, I have woken up to the chirpy voices of my children. I’ve gotten them off to school and their daily activities, poured a cup of green tea and sat down to pray for Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: On ‘S.N.L.,’ President Biden Seeks Help From TikTok Influencers
description: The episode, hosted by Zoë Kravitz, began with Biden briefing a group of creators about the war in Ukraine.
content: It was reported in The Washington Post this week that the Biden administration has been meeting with popular video creators from the social network TikTok and briefing them on the war in Ukraine, an unconventional move that could help the White House in its information battle … or get it made fun of relentlessly.
source.name: The New York Times

title: These Weed Sellers Aren’t Waiting for Permits: ‘Like a Dream Come True’
description: Here’s what it’s like to walk through Washington Square Park in Manhattan in the wake of legalization.
content: Wanting to invest in himself and be free of bosses, Terrence Gorham started selling customized T-shirts, hoodies and backpacks from a folding table in Washington Square Park a year ago. Like any good vendor, he noticed late last year when other tables started featuring something new: weed. Soon, he was offering pre-rolled joints and eighth-of-an-ounce pouches alongside his “Think Rich” clothing line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Tom Brady Says He Will Return to the N.F.L. and the Buccaneers
description: The winning quarterback of seven Super Bowls, Brady said on social media that he would play again next season, after he had announced his retirement in February.
content: After less than six weeks of retirement, it appears that Tom Brady is back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: ‘Think of Groundhogs’: For Life Advice From a Grade Schooler, Press 2
description: A new hotline, an art project by a small California elementary school, was receiving 9,000 calls an hour from people seeking cheerful advice during trying times.
content: If, for some reason, you happen to find yourself feeling overwhelmed or anxious about matters personal, professional or geopolitical, a new hotline offers advice on how to deal with those big feelings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: A Good One Is Square
description: Tune in for Stephen Hiltner’s debut puzzle.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle is a debut by Stephen Hiltner, an editor and photojournalist here at The Times. Mr. Hiltner may be the 19th constructor to make a debut in 2022, but he’s certainly the first Times employee that I’ve seen make a crossword debut during my own (admittedly brief) tenure here. He very kindly contributed the photo at the top of this column, so you can probably understand my bewilderment that someone can be so talented at such different things as crossword construction and photography. I recommend checking out the photojournalism projects linked in Mr. Hiltner’s notes below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Shelling damages a revered monastery, and injures some seeking shelter there.
description: The 16th-century monastery is one of the three most sacred sites in Ukraine for Orthodox believers.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Fighting has damaged a 16th-century monastery and cave complex that is a highly revered Orthodox Christian site for believers in both Russia and Ukraine, according to a church statement, in an incident sure to drive a deeper wedge between the Ukrainian and Russian branches of the church.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Ukrainian refugees find shelter, and a hearty welcome for their pets, in Romania.
description: Viktor and Rachel Borovic had only two hours to prepare to flee their city. But they were clear about what was important to them.
content: SUCEAVA, Romania — Viktor and Rachel Borovic were very grateful to be given a hot meal at a church in Suceava after they crossed from Ukraine into Romania, but they had to turn down the offer of a bed for the night. Their dog, Busia, and their cat, Coco, named after Coco Chanel, were not allowed to stay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: Talking Chaos, or Plotting a Conspiracy? The Debate in the Whitmer Kidnapping Trial.
description: The proceedings that began last week test the government’s ability to root out violent extremism at home.
content: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — Few people took the Covid-19 lockdown restrictions that swept the world in the spring of 2020 harder than the far-right extremist Adam Fox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Weiner
title: 10 Players to Watch in the Women’s N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: As the field expands to 68, there are players throughout the tournament capable of making a splash.
content: Between their highlight reel plays and hard-to-believe statistics, Aliyah Boston, Caitlin Clark and Paige Bueckers have become familiar not only to women’s college basketball fans but to many people with only a passing interest in sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Seven Steps to Destroy a Democracy
description: The Republican-led assault on our elections has been methodical and, so far, successful.
content: We are now living through a fully fledged attack on nonwhite power in this country, as conservative white people assert their authority. Until now, the effects of this crusade were somewhat unclear. Data needed to be collected after new conservative laws and policies had gone into effect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: ‘A Song of Songs’ Makes a Sacrament of Remembrance
description: Grief for a lost love is the unhealed wound at the core of this play by Agnes Borinsky, which takes a disquieting turn into the underworld.
content: A few sheets of colored tissue paper, weighted down by a trinket to keep them from fluttering off. This is what audience members find on their seats upon arrival at “A Song of Songs,” Agnes Borinsky’s new theater piece inspired by the biblical Song of Songs, and it’s something of a puzzle. What to do with them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Monday Briefing: Deadly Airstrikes in Ukraine’s West
description: Plus Omicron’s impact in the South Pacific and the struggles of the French Greens.
content: Russia launched a barrage of airstrikes at a military base that had served as a hub for Western arms shipments near the Polish border, killing at least 35 people and wounding at least 134. Videos show the moment of the attack and the aftermath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Jane Campion Wins Directors Guild Award for ‘The Power of the Dog’
description: Maggie Gyllenhaal also won the first-time filmmaker award. It’s the first year that both trophies went to women.
content: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — The Directors Guild of America awarded its top prize for feature-film directing on Saturday night to Jane Campion for “The Power of the Dog,” making her the third woman ever to receive the award. Her victory also represents the first time in DGA history that women have won that award in back-to-back years, after Chloé Zhao took the prize in 2021 for “Nomadland.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: First Amendment Scholars Want to See the Media Lose These Cases
description: Some legal experts say it is time to draw a sharp line between protected speech and harmful disinformation.
content: The lawyers and First Amendment scholars who have made it their life’s work to defend the well-established but newly threatened constitutional protections for journalists don’t usually root for the media to lose in court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooke Allen
title: The Year That Transformed Dickens (or Did It?)
description: In “The Turning Point,” Robert Douglas-Fairhurst argues that 1851 was pivotal to the novelist and literature itself.
content: THE TURNING POINT1851 — A Year That Changed Charles Dickens and the WorldBy Robert Douglas-Fairhurst
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Renny Cushing, Relentless Foe of the Death Penalty, Dies at 69
description: Even after his father was murdered, he opposed capital punishment and led the effort to repeal it in New Hampshire. Three decades later, he succeeded.
content: Robert R. Cushing Sr., a retired elementary-school teacher, was watching a basketball game on television at his home in New Hampshire in 1988 when he heard a knock at the door. When he answered it, a man fired two blasts from a sawed-off shotgun, killing him in front of his wife, and fled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman and Davide Monteleone
title: The War Next Door
description: In Poland, people watch the unthinkable in Ukraine and worry about the future.
content: USTRZYKI DOLNE, Poland — Polish people know the pain of being invaded. This is what an opera singer told me as she handed out hot stew to Ukrainian refugees in a tent near the mountainous border between Ukraine and Poland on a chilly night in early March. She had planned to go skiing. She came here instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: The ‘Cohen Tax’ Doesn’t Scare the Owner It Is Named For
description: Steven A. Cohen, the Mets’ team owner, has spent lavishly this off-season. Asked if he would surpass the special luxury tax aimed at limiting his spending, he said, “I probably will.”
content: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Steven A. Cohen has been a Major League Baseball club owner only since October 2020. In that short time, he has dramatically changed the trajectory of his team, the Mets, and its spending, the latter of which directly led to a new league payroll tax nicknamed after him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: U.K. vs. Oligarchs: ‘The Gloves Are Now Off’
description: Russia’s war in Ukraine has finally led the British government to go after ultrawealthy Russians in London. But curbing the flood of corrupt money will require going after more than the big names.
content: LONDON — On Friday, the day after Britain blacklisted seven prominent Russian oligarchs, residents of the wealthy London borough of Kensington and Chelsea rolled a washing machine overflowing with fake pound notes in front of a multimillion-dollar townhouse belonging to the family of the president of Azerbaijan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilya Kaminsky
title: Poems in a Time of Crisis
description: Why are so many turning to poetry during this war?
content: Two weeks into the war, the Russians are still menacing my birth city, Odessa, in southwestern Ukraine. It sits on high bluffs above the Black Sea, its famous steps leading from the water to a square.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Two Years Into the Pandemic, Relief, Frustration and Fear as Mandates Ease
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 13, 2022.
content: “Everyone is worn out. Everyone is exhausted. I am as well. But we lost 1,400 Americans yesterday to Covid and we’ll probably lost another 1,400 today. And I don’t think anything has happened that suggests to me that vaccine mandates and mask mandates should be lifted.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Administration Fights in Court to Uphold Some Trump-Era Immigration Policies
description: Immigration activists and Democrats say there is a disconnect between the president’s words at the lectern and the government’s litigation in the courtroom.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden promised to unravel the “moral and national shame” of the immigration policies enacted by President Donald J. Trump. But that was hardly the position Mr. Biden’s lawyers took in a federal courtroom earlier this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: Critics Choice 2022: Complete List of Winners
description: The Critics Choice Awards, which honor both films and TV shows, were held Sunday. The full winners list is below.
content: Follow live coverage of the 2022 Critics Choice Awards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: Generation X Volunteers Want to Help You, and One Day Themselves, Age at Home
description: The Village to Village Network assists older people with the services they need to remain in their homes. A younger generation is getting involved.
content: At 88, Susan McWhinney-Morse is a member of the Silent Generation, so named by some demographers partly for its heads-down, sleeves-up approach to hard work. She fits the industrious profile. But silent she is not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wang Huiyao
title: It’s Time to Offer Russia an Offramp. China Can Help With That.
description: China is uniquely placed to play the role of mediator for economic, political and ideological reasons.
content: Casualties are mounting in Ukraine. Bombs continue to fall. More than 2 million refugees have fled the fighting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Ukraine’s energy minister says power has been restored at Chernobyl nuclear plant.
description: Russian troops have occupied the nuclear power plant since late February.
content: Ukraine’s energy minister said Sunday that power supply has been restored at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant, which Russian troops have occupied since late February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt
title: How Does It End? A Way Out of the Ukraine War Proves Elusive.
description: Attempts at diplomacy have hit a stone wall as President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia refuses to engage in any serious negotiation, but his endgame is unclear.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States accurately predicted the start of the war in Ukraine, sounding the alarm that an invasion was imminent despite Moscow’s denials and Europe’s skepticism. Predicting how it might end is proving far more difficult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: Frustrated With Utilities, Some Californians Are Leaving the Grid
description: Citing more blackouts, wildfires and higher electricity rates, a growing number of homeowners are choosing to build homes that run entirely on solar panels and batteries.
content: NEVADA CITY, Calif. — In the Gold Rush, Northern California attracted prospectors looking for financial independence. Now, this area is at the vanguard of a new movement — people seeking to use only the energy they produce themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Week in Business: Economic Sanctions Take a Toll
description: Prices for gas, food and rent are going up. Mask mandates are ending. And the Fed is expected to raise interest rates.
content: More than two million people have fled Ukraine in the last two weeks as Russia’s invasion of the country claimed thousands of lives and cut off access to water and electricity in some cities. In response to the humanitarian crisis, more than 300 companies have withdrawn at least some operations in Russia, according to a list kept by the Yale School of Management. Retail companies closed stores, fast-food restaurants paused operations and business services firms removed Russian partners from their umbrella networks. But some of these measures have drawbacks. They could hurt Russian civilians or other countries that are allied against Russia. President Vladimir V. Putin accused the United States of waging “an economic war” against Russia on Wednesday and the next day told officials in a televised meeting that the assets of U.S. companies that pull out of Russia should be nationalized.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: California’s Ambitious High-Speed Rail at a Crossroads
description: As President Biden touts an “infrastructure decade,” there is little that’s certain about the biggest infrastructure project of them all.
content: FRESNO, Calif. — On an average day, 1,000 workers head to dozens of construction sites spread over 119 miles across California’s vast Central Valley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman and Vimal Patel
title: Gunman Is Sought in Shooting of 5 Homeless Men in New York and Washington
description: A lone attacker shot the men, two of whom died, as they slept in the street, the authorities said.
content: A gunman has been targeting homeless men sleeping in the streets of Lower Manhattan and Washington and has shot five men, two of them fatally, in recent days, the police in the two cities said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: Being on Leave Means Not Sending That 2 A.M. Email
description: What to do about a boss with enough self-awareness to want to avoid micromanaging but not enough to actually do it.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location or request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: Unsuk Chin on the Violin Concerto She Swore She’d Never Write
description: Unsuk Chin was inspired by Leonidas Kavakos to return to the genre, and the result comes to Carnegie Hall on Monday.
content: The 21st century has been a strong one for violin concertos. Think Jennifer Higdon, whose neo-Romantic showpiece for Hilary Hahn won the Pulitzer Prize in 2010. And Esa-Pekka Salonen, Thomas Adès, Harrison Birtwistle, Jörg Widmann (twice) and John Adams (the same).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Met Museum Names a Mexico City Architect to Lead a New Major Project
description: Frida Escobedo, and not David Chipperfield, will design the Modern and contemporary wing.
content: The Mexican architect Frida Escobedo, who at 38 was the youngest architect to design the Serpentine Pavilion in 2018, has been selected to design the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s new $500 million Modern and contemporary art wing, the museum announced on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: When You Think About Investing, Don’t Think About the News
description: Our columnist spoke with a Nobel laureate, Richard H. Thaler, about how to invest for the long run even if the world seems to be going nuts now.
content: The worse the news, the less you should think about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: Brent Renaud, an American journalist, is killed in Ukraine.
description: An award-winning filmmaker and journalist, Mr. Renaud, 50, was killed while reporting in a suburb of Kyiv. Another journalist was wounded.
content: Brent Renaud, an award-winning American filmmaker and journalist, was killed in Ukraine on Sunday while reporting in a suburb of the capital, Kyiv, according to Ukraine’s Interior Ministry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Approval of travel insurance claims slows as the Omicron wave subsides.
description: Experts say you should expect longer waits for a pay out if you make a travel insurance claim.
content: Before the pandemic, Lauren Mack, 44, a writer based in New York City, “did not routinely purchase travel insurance,” she wrote in an email. Covid-19 convinced her otherwise, and of six trips taken since the onset of the pandemic, she has had to file claims for three — twice for weather delays and once because her travel companion tested positive for the virus. Two are still under review, and the first took nearly two months from claim to reimbursement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: N.C.A.A. Women’s Tournament Set With South Carolina at No. 1 Overall Seed
description: The other top seeds are North Carolina State, Stanford and Louisville. If it keeps winning, UConn, a No. 2 seed, will play every game in its home state until the semifinals.
content: A 68-team field of stalwarts, potential spoilers and national tournament newcomers will play for the N.C.A.A. championship in Division I women’s basketball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lew Serviss and Neil Genzlinger
title: William Hurt, Oscar-Winning Leading Man of the 1980s, Dies at 71
description: A four-time Academy Award nominee, he starred in such films as “Body Heat,” “The Big Chill,” “Kiss of the Spider Woman” and “Broadcast News.”
content: William Hurt, who became a hot Hollywood commodity with his performance as a hapless lawyer in “Body Heat” in 1981 and within a few years had won the best-actor Oscar for the 1985 film “Kiss of the Spider Woman,” in which he portrayed a gay man sharing a Brazilian prison cell with a revolutionary, died at his home in Portland, Ore., on Sunday. He was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Jane Arraf
title: Missiles Fired From Iran Hit Near U.S. Consulate Site in Iraq
description: No serious injuries were reported from the strike, outside the city of Erbil in the Kurdish region of Iraq, and an American official said the consulate site was undamaged.
content: At least a dozen missiles fired from Iran struck near a United States Consulate compound being built outside the city of Erbil in the Kurdish region of Iraq early Sunday, according to Iraqi and U.S. officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Tova Borgnine, Cosmetics Maven and QVC Star, Dies at 80
description: She turned a cactus-derived face mask into a multimillion-dollar beauty business. Her husband, the actor Ernest Borgnine, gave it a surprise assist.
content: Tova Borgnine, the Norwegian-born cosmetics entrepreneur and home-shopping star who was known not just for selling beauty products but also for being the fifth wife and most enduring relationship of the actor Ernest Borgnine, died on Feb. 26 at her home in Chester County, Pa. She was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Zagoria
title: Players to Watch in the N.C.A.A. Men’s Tournament
description: A few of the most noticeable stars of the tournament won’t come from the top-seeded schools.
content: When the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament starts with the play-in games on Tuesday and the round of 64 on Thursday, some of the most noticeable players to watch will come from schools like Bryant, South Dakota State and Seton Hall — not just from the top seeds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Eder
title: As a Crisis Hotline Grows, So Do Fears It Won’t Be Ready
description: Envisioned as the 911 for mental health, the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline will soon be 988, with more services for more callers. But it’s already straining to meet demand.
content: The National Suicide Prevention Lifeline — the number posted on student identification cards, atop Google search results and in warning labels on television shows — is about to get a major reboot, casting it as the 911 for mental health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David S. Cohen, Greer Donley and Rachel Rebouché
title: States Want to Ban Abortions Beyond Their Borders. Here’s What Pro-Choice States Can Do.
description: There’s a new tactic in the coming abortion wars: stopping citizens from getting abortions in other states.
content: A recently introduced Missouri provision would allow private citizens to sue anyone who helps a Missouri resident get an abortion in another state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Naomi Osaka Brought to Tears by Heckler at Indian Wells
description: “I don’t know why, but it went into my head,” said Osaka, who otherwise had ample support from the crowd in her loss to Veronika Kudermetova of Russia.
content: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Crying on court after being heckled by a spectator, Naomi Osaka was knocked out of the BNP Paribas Open in the second round on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Traci Carl
title: Former President Obama tests positive for the coronavirus.
description: He tweeted that he has a scratchy throat but is otherwise fine.
content: Former President Barack Obama said Sunday that he tested positive for the coronavirus and has a scratchy throat but is otherwise fine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rozina Ali, Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Daniel Powell and Zachary Mouton
title: The Sunday Read: ‘What Rashida Tlaib Represents’
description: She changed the Israeli-Palestinian debate in Congress by reminding her colleagues of the human stakes. It’s a burden she would rather not carry.
content: Rozina Ali profiles Rashida Tlaib, the 45-year-old second-term congresswoman from Detroit, who has risen from adverse circumstances to play a significant role in American politics, most notably bringing greater awareness to the ongoing conflict over Palestine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $775,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Saudi Arabia Puts 81 to Death, Despite Promises to Curb Executions
description: It was the kingdom’s largest mass execution in years. In many cases, the charges involved “not a drop of blood,” a rights activist said.
content: CAIRO — Saudi Arabia said on Saturday that it had put 81 people to death in what was the kingdom’s largest mass execution in years, despite recent promises to curb its use of the death penalty.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Driver Motioned for My Friend to Hand Over the Phone’
description: Heading home after a night of dancing, a dog with good intentions and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Eastern Orthodox Leaders Are Outspoken on Ukraine War. Except One.
description: The Russian Orthodox Church is allied with President Putin. But in New York, some of its members are quietly anguished.
content: Last week, more than a dozen religious and political leaders sat on the dais of the Ukrainian Orthodox Cathedral of Saint Volodymyr on the Upper West Side, listening to solemn prayers and fiery speeches denouncing Russia and extolling Ukrainian resistance to the invasion that began two weeks earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: Time is running out for civilians in Mariupol, Red Cross warns.
description: Russian forces encircled the city nearly two weeks ago, and as the death toll rises, eyewitnesses have reported there is little food or clean water, and no medicine.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — At least 2,187 people in the coastal city of Mariupol have died since the start of the war, Ukraine’s government said Sunday, as the International Committee of the Red Cross warned that time was running out for hundreds of thousands of civilians still trapped in the besieged city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Trinity Church’s Conductor Put on Leave Amid Investigation
description: Julian Wachner has been accused of sexually assaulting a Juilliard School employee during a music festival in 2014. He denies the accusation.
content: Trinity Wall Street, one of New York’s wealthiest and most powerful churches, said on Saturday that it was placing its high-profile director of music on leave as it investigates an allegation of sexual misconduct against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: A ‘Rock Wall’ Let the United States Flex Its Hockey Might
description: A dominant run in which Jen Lee and the Americans outscored their opponents, 18-1, culminated in a 5-0 win over Canada in the gold medal game.
content: BEIJING — The tears started flowing from Jen Lee’s eyes the moment the horn sounded to signal that the United States had beaten Canada, 5-0, to win its fourth consecutive gold medal in Paralympic sled hockey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Unvaccinated M.L.B. players will not be allowed to play in Canada.
description: Canada’s border restrictions bar those players, and the players will not be paid while the team is abroad as part of the sport’s new labor agreement.
content: Major League Baseball players who are not vaccinated against the coronavirus will not be allowed to enter Canada to play games against the Toronto Blue Jays because of the country’s restrictions, and they will not be paid while the team is abroad as part of the sport’s new labor agreement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Jack Nicas and Eric Schmitt
title: Russian Airstrike at NATO’s Doorstep Raises Fears of Expanded War
description: Russian missiles hit a military base being used to train foreign volunteers who want to help Ukraine repel the invasion, killing a reported 35 people just 11 miles from the Polish border.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — Russia launched a barrage of airstrikes on Sunday against a military base in western Ukraine where American troops had trained Ukrainian forces just weeks earlier, bringing the war 11 miles from the border with Poland, where NATO forces are stationed on high alert.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: On a Stage 5,000 Miles Away, He Sings for His Family in Ukraine
description: At the Metropolitan Opera, the bass-baritone Vladyslav Buialskyi has become a symbol of his country’s struggles.
content: Sometimes lately, when he hasn’t been rehearsing Verdi or Tchaikovsky at the Metropolitan Opera, or practicing Italian with a diction coach on Zoom, the bass-baritone Vladyslav Buialskyi takes out his phone and sends a one-word text message: “Mama.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins and Yousur Al-Hlou
title: Booms, Smoke and Fire Signal Horror of Russian Attack on Base
description: Residents of a town near Poland’s border awoke to frightful sounds and an awareness they were no longer safe.
content: NOVOYAVORIVSK, Ukraine — Hours after Russian missiles decimated a military base near the Polish border on Sunday, soldiers in camouflage were still being wheeled out of an overwhelmed nearby hospital on stretchers, many in so much pain they could only turn their heads to reveal eyes stricken with fear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: South Korea exceeds 380,000 new cases in a day shortly after its presidential election.
description: South Korea reported another record for daily new coronavirus cases over the weekend, reaching 383,665 known cases on Saturday, according to the government — a fresh reminder that cases have yet to peak during the current surge that is being fueled by the highly contagious Omicron variant. Public health experts had projected at the end of February that new cases would reach 350,000 a day by the end of March, and it was unclear whether predictions for a peak had been reset.
content: South Korea reported another record for daily new coronavirus cases over the weekend, reaching 383,665 known cases on Saturday, according to the government — a fresh reminder that cases have yet to peak during the current surge that is being fueled by the highly contagious Omicron variant. Public health experts had projected at the end of February that new cases would reach 350,000 a day by the end of March, and it was unclear whether predictions for a peak had been reset.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Europe Awakens
description: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has unexpectedly transformed Europe.
content: Europe’s assertive response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has presented a possibility that was hard to imagine a month ago: the European Union as a superpower that can alter the global order, promoting liberal democratic values worldwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen and Gabriella Angotti-Jones
title: Pro Boxing Gains Another Father-Son Duo
description: Giovanni Marquez, son of the former world junior middleweight champion Raul Marquez, won his professional debut, with his father going from trainer to broadcaster.
content: During a Showtime boxing broadcast in February, one of the network’s analysts, Raul Marquez, praised a Houston welterweight as a “tough guy” who had sparred with his son Giovanni, a promising amateur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Zucchino and Yaqoob Akbary
title: Afghan Aviators Hide as Taliban Urge Them to Return to Duty
description: Many former Afghan Air Force members fear they could be killed by the Taliban if they came out of hiding, but others have joined the nascent Taliban air force.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Last year, the three Afghan aviators served in the elite Special Mission Wing of the Afghan Air Force. Trained by Americans to fight the Taliban from the air, they were some of the Afghan military’s most elite troops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: With cases still rising in Hong Kong, 300,000 people are isolating at home, officials say.
description: The city’s officials are scrambling to build quarantine and mass quarantine centers as cases of the Omicron and Delta variants spread widely.
content: HONG KONG — As many as 300,000 Hong Kong residents are isolating at home, the city’s leader said on Sunday, as officials scrambled to build mass quarantine centers and treatment facilities to house patients with even the mildest Covid-19 symptoms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: N.C.A.A. Men’s Tournament Seedings Set as Spectacle Returns to March
description: Gonzaga, Arizona, Kansas and Baylor earned the four No. 1 seeds in the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament.
content: When the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament pairings were announced Sunday night, it served as one big welcome mat for the sport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: 2022 N.C.A.A. Men’s Tournament Bracket
description: Gonzaga, Arizona, Kansas and Baylor are the top seeds in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament.
content: Gonzaga, Arizona, Kansas and Baylor are the top seeds in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Red Carpet Fashion at the 2022 Critics Choice Awards
description: The 27th annual Critics Choice Awards may shine some light on the Oscars race. See the stars as they made their way down the red carpet.
content: The 27th annual Critics Choice Awards may shine some light on the Oscars race. See the stars as they made their way down the red carpet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Recharge with new and comforting dishes like saffron pistachio brownies and the Big Lasagna.
content: Good morning. How are you doing? I’m moved to ask that question every couple of months because I think it’s important to acknowledge that you might not be doing well at all. We are two years into the pandemic and some two weeks into the war in Ukraine. There’s heartbreak everywhere, and there are times for all of us when it seems too much to bear.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 13, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, March 13, 2022.
content: An article on Page 18 this weekend about the movie “The Godfather” and its similarities to the real life mafia misspells the name of the author of “The Five Families: The Rise, Decline, and Resurgence of America’s Most Powerful Mafia Empires.” He is Selwyn Raab, not Rabb. The article also describes incorrectly a recording of two mobsters in 2005. The recordings were made in person, not over the telephone.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Likely Is Another Civil War?
description: Readers discuss whether the U.S. is headed for another civil war.  Also: Asian American voters; Supreme Court nominations; disinformation; Covid origins; President Biden and the heartland.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
